channel.description: Recent content in BHSA on Albert De La Fuente's site

item.title: Analyzing the Biblia Hebraica Stuttgartensia with Text Fabric in Python
item.description:
I am very curious about Hebrew, specially the way the language is hierarchically designed. Three letter words are commonly known as trilateral roots and the rest of the words are variation of these three letters and categorized under the same family. I am not going to get into these details since it is not the scope of this post.

Long story short, the journey of trying to learn Hebrew started probably between 2006 to 2008 and I haven’t had much success at it. Or lets say that the expectations don’t match reality =P. So I thought that I could try to somehow start with the most common words in the scriptures and that is what motivated to parse the Aleppo codex and analyze its content in python. I quickly learned that my approach was rather naive given the prefixes that causes variations to the words, even thought the meaning of the word itself is the same.

This blog post is a second attempt to tackle the same problem but with a more sophisticated linguistic approach using Text Fabric.

A corpus of ancient texts and (linguistic) annotations represents a large body of knowledge.

Text-Fabric is a Python package for processing and access a corpus of ancient text and linguistic annotations. In this specific case I am using the Hebrew Bible Database, containing the text of the Hebrew Bible augmented with linguistic annotations compiled by the Eep Talstra Centre for Bible and Computer, VU University Amsterdam.

The text is based on the Biblia Hebraica Stuttgartensia edited by Karl Elliger and Wilhelm Rudolph, Fifth Revised Edition, edited by Adrian Schenker, Â© 1977 and 1997 Deutsche Bibelgesellschaft, Stuttgart.

The text-fabric version has been prepared by Dirk Roorda Data Archiving and Networked Services, with thanks to Martijn Naaijer, Cody Kingham, and Constantijn Sikkel.

It is amazing to see the work these researchers did compiling all this data and making it public for free. I am very thankful for it.

I am using a literate programming approach with Doom Emacs and org-mode.

Create the virtual environment

virtualenv ~/.workon-home/venv-textfabric
cd ~/.workon-home/venv-textfabric
source ./bin/activate.fish
pip install text-fabric pandas requests

Activate the virtual environment

Use C-c here on Doom Emacs

(pyvenv-activate "~/.workon-home/venv-textfabric")

Load the ETCBC/bhsa dataset

Use run-python and ober-eval-block-in-repl to evaluate each block (C-c r at the time being). For the sake of a more practical approach to writing using literate programming the output of the blocks will follow the code.

from tf.app import use
import os
import collections
from itertools import chain

A = use("ETCBC/bhsa", hoist=globals())

A.indent(reset=True)
A.info("counting objects ...")

for otype in F.otype.all:
    i = 0

    A.indent(level=1, reset=True)

    for n in F.otype.s(otype):
        i += 1

    A.info("{:>7} {}s".format(i, otype))

A.indent(level=0)
A.info("Done")

**Locating corpus resources ...**
app: ~/text-fabric-data/github/ETCBC/bhsa/app
data: ~/text-fabric-data/github/ETCBC/bhsa/tf/2021
data: ~/text-fabric-data/github/ETCBC/phono/tf/2021
data: ~/text-fabric-data/github/ETCBC/parallels/tf/2021
Text-Fabric:
	Text-Fabric API 12.0.5 => https:/annotation.github.io/text-fabric/tf/cheatsheet.html
	ETCBC/bhsa/app  v3 => https:/github.com/ETCBC/bhsa/blob/master/app

Data:
	ETCBC - bhsa 2021 => https:/ETCBC.github.io/bhsa/
	Character table => https:/annotation.github.io/text-fabric/tf/writing/hebrew.html
	Feature docs => https:/ETCBC.github.io/bhsa/features/0_home
Node types:

BHSA = Biblia Hebraica Stuttgartensia Amstelodamensis

	otype

	pdp                  â phrase dependent part-of-speech (art; verb; subs; nmpr, ...)

	typ                  â clause/phrase(atom) type (VP; NP; Ellp; Ptcp; WayX)

	voc_lex              â vocalized lexeme pointed-transliterated (B.: R;>CIJT BR> >:ELOHIJM)
	voc_lex_utf8         â vocalized lexeme pointed-Hebrew (×Ö¼Ö° ×¨Öµ××©×Ö´××ª ××¨× ×Ö±×Ö¹×Ö´××)
	vs                   â verbal stem (qal; piel; hif; apel; pael)
	vt                   â verbal tense (perf; impv; wayq; infc)
	mother               â linguistic dependency between textual objects
	oslots

Phonetic Transcriptions
	phono                ð phonological transcription (báµ rÄÅ¡ËÃ®á¹¯ bÄrËÄ ÊáµlÅhËÃ®m)
	phono_trailer        ð interword material in phonological transcription

  0.00s counting objects ...
   |     0.00s      39 books
   |     0.00s     929 chapters
   |     0.00s    9230 lexs
   |     0.00s   23213 verses
   |     0.00s   45179 half_verses
   |     0.01s   63717 sentences
   |     0.01s   64514 sentence_atoms
   |     0.01s   88131 clauses
   |     0.01s   90704 clause_atoms
   |     0.03s  253203 phrases
   |     0.03s  267532 phrase_atoms
   |     0.01s  113850 subphrases
   |     0.05s  426590 words
  0.15s Done

Analizing some lexemes

Text-Fabric allows to query the “types” of words. We can do this by using:

print(F.sp.freqList())

(('subs', 125583), ('verb', 75451), ('prep', 73298), ('conj', 62737), ('nmpr', 35607), ('art', 30387), ('adjv', 10141), ('nega', 6059), ('prps', 5035), ('advb', 4603), ('prde', 2678), ('intj', 1912), ('inrg', 1303), ('prin', 1026))

Defining some help functions

These functions will facilitate the processing of the data. The first one will get the occurrences of a specific type of lexeme. I am not a linguist so I am learning on the go and I will try to explain it easily. The most common lexeme verb is ×××¨ (say). It appears 5307 times. We can see that Yah indeed wants to communicate and instruct us.

A specific instance of that verb has other properties (node features) like morphology which contains the verbal stem (qal, piel, nif, hif), the verbal tense (perf, impf, wayq) and gender (m, f) among other information.

import pandas as pd

def get_lexeme_by_type(lex_type):
    rows = []
    A.indent(reset=True)
    #A.info("Collecting data")
    for w in F.otype.s("lex"):
        if F.sp.v(w) != lex_type:
            continue
        row = {'w': w,
               'freq_lex': F.freq_lex.v(w),
               'sp': F.sp.v(w),
               'lex_utf8': F.lex_utf8.v(w),
               #'g_word_utf8': F.g_word_utf8.v(w),
               'gloss': F.gloss.v(w),
               #'gn': F.gn.v(w),
               #'nu': F.nu.v(w),
               #'ps': F.ps.v(w),
               #'st': F.st.v(w),
               #'vs': F.vs.v(w),
               #'vt': F.vt.v(w),
               #'book': F.book.v(w),
               }
        rows.append(row)
    #A.info("Done")
    df = pd.DataFrame(rows)
    return(df)

def pp_sorted_df(input_df, rows_qty):
    sorted_df = input_df.sort_values(by=['freq_lex'], ascending=False)
    output_df = sorted_df.head(rows_qty)
    return([list(output_df)] + [None] + output_df.values.tolist())

Printing the most frequent verbs (lexemes)

Here is a list with the top 100 verbs sorted by frequency.

verbs = get_lexeme_by_type('verb')
print_df = pp_sorted_df(sorted_verbs, 100)
w freq_lex sp lex_utf8 gloss

Here we can see the id of the lexeme (w), the frequency (freq_lex), the utf8 representation of the word without vowel pointing and the english meaning used for the translation. All automatically, pretty cool isn’t it?

  • Top 12 verbs with strongs

    Out of those, I wanted to map also the pronunciation, Strong numbers and the full meaning from BLB so I created this table. Note that the strong number as the pronunciation are just probable, since I am working with lexemes rather than words.

    Pronun. Word Qty Meaning Strongs
    aw-mar' ×××¨ 5379 To say, speak, utter KJV H559
    haw-yaw ××× 3561 to be, become, come to pass, exist, happen, fall out KJV H1961
    aw-saw' ×¢×©×× 2629 to do, fashion, accomplish, make KJV H6213
    bo ××× 2570 to go in, enter, come, go, come in KJV H935
    naw-than' × ×ª× 2017 to give, put, set KJV H5414
    haw-lak' ××× 1554 to go, walk, come KJV H1980
    raw-aw' ×¨×× 1298 to see, look at, inspect, perceive, consider KJV H7200
    shaw-mah' ×©×××¢ 1168 to hear, listen to, obey WLC H885
    daw-bar' ×××¨ 1143 to speak, command, promise, warn, threaten, sing KJV H1696
    yaw-shab' ××©×× 1082 to dwell, remain, sit, abide KJV H3427
    yaw-tsaw' ××¦× 1069 to go out, come out, exit, go forth KJV H3318
    shoob ×©××× 1056 to return, turn back KJV H7725

    I made this list by hand, which is not very practical for automation, so I wonder if there is a better way to get the Strong numbers automatically. I don’t have an answer for this at this time, but this repository looks promising: https://github.com/eliranwong/BHS-Strong-no/blob/master/brief_info_ETCBC_lex.csv.

    I still have some work that is not documented, so this is work in progress. I am still learning how to properly use TF’s API.

    As a side note I also found word by word on BHS 5th edition here: https://github.com/eliranwong/MP3_BHS5_word-by-word. I am very excited about this finding. Also it is worthwhile checking out this: https://github.com/eliranwong/UniqueBible.
